content: Today is the day. Thought I would mention it because it and Easter seem to have so little visibility on the social map anymore. When I worked in private sector, we always had Good Friday off, though I'm not 100% sure if that's still the case , as it's been 12 years ago. Now that I'm a Federal employee, I would have to plan to take leave if I wanted to observe the day that has so much meaning for me as a Christian. Life has changed a lot since I was a pup. It's hard to find a nice Easter card anymore, but there are fully packed store aisles with candy and baskets and toys. Seems like the priorities are leaning toward the materialistic things, and the spiritual things are getting lost in the shuffle.

content: Hello Orange Cat97 ---- Thanks for the Post. For decades in Smogifornia Good Friday was (is?) a Bank holiday. They close the doors at Noon. Amen! Went to a Lutheran Church (WELS) Good Friday service once many moons ago... it was a good reminder of the crucifixion. Thre were no flowers up front and the pulpit and alter were draped with black cloth (death). There are 3 good "Collects" (group prayers) in the Book of Common Prayer 1928 -(Google it: Anglicans Online or the Prayer Book Society, USA) for Good Friday. They are found on page 156 if you have access to a 1928 Cambridge edition BCP. Deep and profound and rich in wording. This message has been edited. content: Ah, yes! The good old days of youth. During the week between Palm Sunday and Easter Sunday, we would be wrestled down and fitted for Easter clothes and shoes. On Easter Sunday we would all go to church with our Easter clothing on. I suspect that the Easter Dressup was a holdover from when my mom was the daughter of a sharecropper and that after a long winter of dreary days and cold nights, they welcomed a chance to 'emerge anew' just as the daffolills had done. I miss some of the old ways. However, Easter is a time to rejoice in the newness of life, especially Spiritual life. These are my opinions. Yours may differ.

content: It is. Tomorrow is Vigil, yesterday was Maunday Thursday. Tonight I hope to get to church, but the screaming "I'm tired" fits my 18 month old has been throwing at 1845 nightly may prevent it. We've been strategizing all day on how to keep it from happening. I pray we can. Has anyone else ever seen Bach's "St Matthews Passion" performed live? We went last year the week before Holy Week. It was very powerful, the opening scene is the crowds chanting to come and share in the mourning and to see the sacrifice. They set it up so that you were physically part of the crowd (half the choir was behind the audience). They did the same during the portion when the crowds yell "crucify him" When I was a kid in RI we got Good Friday off from school. 95% of my town was Roman Catholic (I was in the 5% as a LCMS Lutheran) So I think that played into it, though not sure if that still holds. Here, the kids still have school. Blessed Good Friday to all of you. We will rejoice on Sunday when he is risen again!

content: quote: Originally posted by catherine0830: Blessed Good Friday to all of you. We will rejoice on Sunday when he is risen again! * A somber day indeed Kat – good thread * Meditation: (from Once Upon a Tree: Devotional Essays on the Cross by Calvin Miller.) Please read the following excerpt and see yourself in the author’s words. “At the exact pinpoint of time where nothing moves, I find both excellence and shame – His sacrificial death standing embarrassingly close to my self-centeredness. I bring my greed and beg His generosity. I bring my tendency to whimper and marvel again how far suffering is willing to go.” “I’ve asked myself what it is that should so immediately bind His execution to my wholeness. I am left dumbfounded at the proposition. I cannot say why my own freedom forms the very pinions that hold Him to the sky. But suddenly I realize that I am stalked by a great love incapable of quitting its pursuit.” “Most of the time we are alone at Calvary – just the two of us. The centurion, the Pharisees, the thieves, the bystanders – all disappear and leave us uncomfortably alone, just Jesus and myself, host to each other in a dialogue of Spirit. At such moments I do not philosophize, only marvel. In beholding Him as He is I cringe at what I am. But He assures me that I am immeasurably valuable to God. “Bid my hands,” He says, “And you will know how great is your value unto My Father.” Here is love – the final ecstasy of man welded to the last agony of God.” * choose joy each day
